commentBody:
Didn't get the theme until after I solved the puzzle and then it gave me an actual laugh. D/WASHBOARD took me a second but when I got it I laughed again.

Kudos.

Imagine my surprise when I completed the puzzle with only one letter per square and several rebuses about which I’d had no clue popped up.  I guess it was a stealth rebus.  I can appreciate the ingenuity of the construction, but I do prefer rebus puzzles that require the solver to actually see the rebus to solve the puzzle.
Briliiant

Well done Mr. Boroughs, well done. I picked up the theme quickly, but stumbled a bit over ODIC. I'd plugged ODES in, and raced through the puzzle, but had to backtrack to find my booboo. Still beat my average tho.
Also didnt get the theme till the end. I had chaned some of the Ws to Ds, so I had all Ds in the circles.

Odic? Haven't heard ECHOPARK, so EsHO PARK sounded just as right. FeSHTAIL seemed like it could have been FISHTAIL, but I was more convinced ODes was right than I was that the other answers were wrong

Impressive! I found this to be relatively easy work - likely due to the fact that the themers all had two valid and accessible solutions. 

The beauty of a puzzle like this is the admiration the solver feels for the constructor, more so than the mental workout. Thanks, Grant Boroughs
is the femur the longest or the largest? Had a bit of trouble with that.

Loved it! Finally caught on when I realised I might be WINED or DINED. 
The ingenuity and patience of Mr Boroughs is to be admired!

I completed the puzzle online and it's still giving me a message that there's an error somewhere. I put a D in each circle, then tried a W and even W/D but still happening. I checked every other word and all is correct so is anyone else having an issue?

What a stroke of genius!
The themers and revealer, yes, but also the intelligent clues, as well as the smart misdirects peppered throughout.

I don't remember exactly when the penny dropped for me since my solving m.o. is to always float around the grid, criss-crossing as I go. 
But when it did, I took myself straight to the revealer, where I had the ORD in place, and excitedly filled in the rest, W-OR-D CHOICE, astonished and gleeful. 

I can't even imagine what a bear this must have been to construct, Mr. Boroughs, but please know that your gift to us has been received with awe and gratitude.

Very fine puzzle.

I'm expecting a lot of agreement, and a lot of disagreement.

Gotta love Thursday.
Fun, fast, and clever.

For those who are really worried whether it is alive or dead, I checked on the cat.


Yes.



cc: emu handler
Not registering as solved on android app. Tried all the permutations, nothing works.
Ver impressive! I figured it out having to choose between wry humor and dry humor because I never really know the difference either. Love this puzzle.

I saw COW and DASHBOARDS, but not COD and WASHBOARDS, so I thought it was different for across and down.  I had a vague expectation of Washer/Dryer appearing in the revealer.  Possibly something about "stacked appliances"? Dunno, just finished laundry for the week, so it was on my mind.

Very easy for a Thursday.

Cute.  I liked it better after I finished it.  The only double answers I truly got were wash/dash and day/way.

It wasn't particularly fun to solve for me. Unlike the Wordplay author the "revealer" made sense to me immediately, but I thought it was a mix of circled Ws and Ds, not a full on Schrodinger situation.  Oh well.  Decent enough puzzle.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)

Whoa, (so sorry that whoa can't start with a d!), that was fun! 

I was a little slow to pick up on the actual theme but once I did, what a delight! 

Fun and surprisingly fast for me! I'm on my phone app, so I'm not sure but I think it was a Thursday best... But more importantly is how lovely it was to complete and to slowly realize what was happening!

I do confess to kind of wishing 31A had something to do with Bugs Bunny, with that potentially hidden capital letter....  That said, I actually really liked the clue and answer as presented!

Really, very fun and lovely! I've heard out here about Schrödinger's puzzles but how delightful to find myself in one!

My compliments to the chef!! 😘

And furthermore.....


Is it me or has this just been an exceptionally fun week of puzzles!? 


Inquiring emus want to know!!

Schrödinger puzzles are such a challenge to create, it’s easy to see why they are such rare occurrences. But what a thrill to be treated to one of these construction marvels. They are awe inspiring and provide some of the most satisfying aha moments. This one was no exception. 

Congratulations, Grant. Great work!

Fantastic!
Washboard/Dashboard!
Wishes/Dishes!
The cat in the box is definitely alive after doing this fun puzzle.

In other news:
I’m giving up changing my location using What3Words - the emus have decided it must mean something nefarious to move around so much; my Sunday post never appeared.

In other other news:
While hiking yesterday (OK, near fidelity.windpipe.basher), best beloved was up ahead of me. I had got my phone out to look at my GPS app. He turned around and said (accusingly): “are you doing the puzzle?!” I felt so seen.
I solved it without actually completely solving it (but it still counts).
I put only a D or W for some. Since they were accepted, I'm guessing there is no way to change them to WD? I can't edit a square after it's accepted as correct.

I enjoyed the theme but personally didn't enjoy the honorific clues because I didn't know either one and found a couple of the crossings inscrutable - namely "Burnt bit of brisket" and "Stopover". 

When I eventually looked up the honorifics, the crossings kind of made sense but they weren't my favorite clues. I also had the femur as LonGEST instead of LARGEST which was throwing things off. And sports clues like the one involving Cy Young are always my Achilles heel. 

Oh well, live and learn.

Impressive construction! Clues were on the easy side. Finished well below average, with no lookups. 

I started with COW and PAW, but WASHBOARDS and WITHER made less sense to me than DASHBOARDS and DITHER. So switched to D, and thought the theme (on a Thursday?) required a D in every circle. That sped up my solve considerably. 

Though I had LONGEST for Femur, and only switched to LARGEST when NENEWAL didn’t make sense. Then SAHIB clicked as well. ODD before OFF.  RUNS AMOK before RUNS RIOT. But all very gettable. 

Didn’t get the theme till the end, and had to read the revealer clue a few times to understand how to parse WORD as W OR D. That was a very clever twist!!  Went over all theme answers to see how they worked with W and that felt quite satisfactory. 

Well done, Grant!

"Should I use a thesaurus for this word or call my writer friend?"
"Well, one way or an author."

("Roget that.")

"I finished the puzzle and felt chuffed, but I still couldn’t make sense of the revealer and how it related to the theme." Same here. I'm not sure how I feel about that. I guess it's clever, but since it was lost on me it wasn't that satisfying. I hope others had the epiphany while solving and could appreciate it during the process, which is way better.

I guess I'm happy that it makes some folks feel clever.  But these rebi are just getting so out of reach for all but a few, that they ruin enjoyment of the puzzles.  Yesterday's, for example (i.e. the lightning puzzle) was clever and enjoyable.  It didn't require a massive stretch of the imagination, but it did require some effort.  This one?  Just seems like only the lucky stumble across the gimmick...I would send this puzzle through the W/D cycle a few times and clean it up.

The theme largely escaped me - I was as mentally inflexible as ever, despite trying to think outside the box (the box being the irritatingly narrow confines of my intellectual abilities). I never considered Ds for the circled letters. Once I had a few Ws there, I put Ws in the other circles, too, and that helped me complete the puzzle.

I mean, I knew there had to be more to theme - the revealer had nothing to do with Ws after all - but I was not smart enough to understand the whole thing. My life so far has proved I am not particularly  intellectually challenged, but I *do* miss a certain ability to grasp unusual, abstract concepts. I just can't see anything else there when what I'm seeing is familiar at first glance: WORDCHOICE is just "word choice" to me and my circuits would fry before I parsed that as "w or d choice" - even with an indication to do so.

Still, I completed the puzzle without lookups, even though I was tempted to Google some of the trivia. In the end I needed to check one single square at the crossing of S_HIB and the femur clue - I think of bones not as large but rather as long, and LonGEST worked for many entries around there. I knew we spell SAHIB with an A in Polish but I thought maybe English uses an O there? It's happened before.

ODIC rather than ODes was so cruel it made me laugh 🤣. I figured it out on my own though.

Also, I don't understand WISHES as a thing listed on a wedding registry. It's not a thing in Poland. Could somebody explain please?
I have to go look again… I finished in such record (for me) time that I came here to find out why it was a Thursday!

I take my NY times daily crossword very seriously. I use Google  crossword answers to solve  questions that I don't know. Why is it that the questions that you ask are not on Google. Its very frustrating. I would like to know that. Hope some one will email me an answer. I don't like it when I can't solve my  crossword puzzle. I do it every day. I'm almost 84, trying to keep my brain sharp

A fun distraction from Milton, our temporary neighbor this evening. As I write this, we're on the backside of the eye (we missed being in the eye by about 5 miles as it went by south of us) and are finally (unfortunately) getting some of the higher velocity wind gusts, whereas, before, we mostly had rain. We've had one momentary power glitch, which shut off the TV and the computer, but got those restarted and got at the puzzle afterward.

Dawned on me halfway through the puzzle that we had spots where both W and D would work, and the revealer was spot on.

Thanks, Grant.
Outstanding puzzle. Love the different layers of solving. Thursdays should always be the most esthetically pleasing of the week.
Fresh, fantastic and fully enjoyable!
WISHES / DISHES I was fine with, but I don't entirely understand WITHER as a clue (not helped by the Scottish word SWITHER, which does fit the clue better)

If we are waxing philosophical, IMHO this puzzle exceeds the Aristotelian definition of wit. It is in the wheelhouse of his definition of genius: « an intuitive perception of the similarity in dissimilars" which « cannot be taught by another ».* Thank you, Grant Boroughs. Not least of all because the emu is so happy to have been included in your puzzle today. It SASHAYS in pride as I write. *See Andrew M. Stewart: https://digitalcommons.denison.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1074&context=episteme#:~:text=Recall that Aristotle thinks that,are rightly defined as arts.

I stared at 58A for quite a long time and am really chuffed that I did as it finally came to me and I went back to check all the circles and sure enough, either a W or a D was correct.  What a great AHA moment.  

A fine Thursday puzzle, well done, Grant.
fun puzzle! Love the hidden theme of ZOOM, black ICE, FISHTAIL, and SCRAP! I wonder if it was intentional or by pure ACCIDENT ;)
This puzzle was so much fun! Just what I needed today. Thank you!

Since PAW and COW were some of my first confident entries, I started automatically putting W’s in the circled squares, which meant I didn’t ever consider of any of the “D” answers— I just thought “what would start with a W here that answers the clue?” I had everything in besides the north-central section (Cy Young sounded like a book award to me, ha) and I started to doubt myself when I suspected BOWL for 16D. Why isn’t that W circled?? 

I still made it to the end without figuring out the theme, which was a bummer for my ego since I just *love* the smug satisfaction of cracking a Thursday. That being said, I’m thoroughly charmed by the clever W-OR-D play, bruised ego and all. 🙃 Thank you for a thoughtful puzzle!! 

And as always, appreciate the column & comments that help me learn new things, get unstuck, and think about things differently for future puzzles.

Not tricky, but I appreciate the clever construction. The revealer made it extra fun. And, for those unfamiliar with WASHBOARD as a musical instrument: Buckwheat Zydeco and Washboard Jo: https://youtu.be/t8GIi6G7ti4?si=gn_PmEOEGOgAyppj
Nice puzzle with multiple possible answers to the same clue with none of them being particularly far out or even remotely related to the clue.

Such a *choice* puzzle!

I dunno, do I go with DISHES or WISHES?
PAW or PAD?
DASHBOARD or WASHBOARD?

My puzzle, my choice!

Next level and very forgiving!
👍 👍

Very clever, well clued puzzle. Nicely done. I'd offer "not a Thursday". I'm sure things will settle out over time but I've had recurring thoughts recently that today's puzzle isn't a today's puzzle. Sometimes too difficult. Sometimes too easy. Because Wednesday is my favorite puzzle day of the week, I loved this puzzle.

From a post by Games Moderator Greg Mills, in yesterday's comments, rather late in the day: "For several months, we’ve been quietly cooking up a new phrase guessing puzzle, Zorse, and we released a beta version this week. The catch? It’s only available in Canada (for now). You can learn more about our beta testing process by reading this FAQ put together by our customer care team: https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/24174502647444-Beta-Games/" Are my in-laws and their compatriots mere guinea pigs to the NYT? *Beta* dogs in the Puzzling Pack? DASHBOARD, sure, but WASHBOARD? Was this a slang term for some instrument display, one I wasn't familiar with? Oh wait--a panel which *is* a (musical) instrument! Hah-hah! Thanks to @Nancy J for including a link, so I don't hsave to Finally, Grant, this one goes out to you: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H9J90hkGytQ (Dónde está mi teléphono?)

Wow. Just - wow. What an incredible feat of construction. Anyway - typical long workout for me, but managed to get it all together, but... never caught on to the trick until I went to Xword Info to review. I probably couldn't even tell you in which squares I used W and which ones D.

Just incredibly amazing that the constructor was able to find all those D or W answers of the same length, both of which fit the clue, and then was able to fit them all in the same puzzle the way he did.  I can't even imagine what a long struggle that must have been. 

Puzzle of the week? Month? Year? - I'd say yes to all of those. 

..

Now seems to me to be a good time to remind everyone of the Schrödinger puzzle to end all Schrödinger puzzles, which ran on Election Day, Nov. 5, 1996, the year Bill Clinton ran against Bob Dole.

You can find it in the Archives.  I won't say more about it because saying that it's a Schrödinger puzzle is spoiler enough.

Sometimes the solving experience suffers because the cluing is compromised a bit to make the theme work. Not today. This theme served the puzzle instead of the other way around. It was a pleasure to work through this challenging, well constructed gem and the theme was a brilliant sparkle of fairy dust on top.

Well, well, aren't YOU the tricky one, Grant B!?
SIX Themers PLUS a Reveal--quite the feat!
I felt my heart sink when I saw two neighborhoods (in places I've never lived) and (arrgh) Scooby-doo and "Twilight" (never watched) ugh ugh ugh! But then Aristotle, Caesar, honorifics, and cheese!

I also fell into the traps with LONGEST, RUNS AMOK, DALES (although I left blanks just in case) and HA HA HA, so I hope this makes you smile.  

Wonderful puzzle, had a great time, and hope to see you again soon, you rascal!
Absolutely genius. Loved it.

Another Thursday puzzle that I solved without really understand ing it. 

Some of the cluing seemed a little strained. "I'm Flexible" comes out as ANY?  "Stopover" is INN? But OK.  

Was fun when the music played and it showed on (on my computer) the squares with the word choices demonstrated. 

Happy to solve it without cheating and looking at the wordplay blog.

and onward!
The theme reminded me of the dilemma I faced this morning. what to have for breakfast: W(waffles) or D(donut)? I resolved it by eating Oatmeal instead.

This was fun! I thought the cluing was on the easier side. Multiple points where I felt like I was on the same wavelength as the constructor. I solved from the bottom up today, getting a little stuck in the NE corner (I wasn't thinking literally enough about a dog's leg, though I immediately got ANI and some of the other more literal clues). I had the revealer clue solved early on, but it was delightful once I looked a little closer and figured it out what it actually meant for the circled squares.

Finished at the midway point between my best and average time for Thursdays.
Nice job, fun to solve, and finally, great rebus.  Thank you.

A real hum-dinger of a Schrö-dinger. Nicely done!







cc: emu handler

For some reason, I managed to pick up on the theme from the very first instance (1D/15A). Pre-filling “D/W” in every circle led to what might be my fastest Thursday solve yet! Sometimes you and the constructor are just on the same wavelength.

Two tools to solve any problem:  duct tape and WD-40.
I was looking for the WD-40 for today's puzzle.

Luckily, we still have power and internet this morning, but winds are ramping up.
Florida is in baaaad shape.

Strands needed neither duct tape nor WD-40.
Strands #221
“Think about it”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵
I solved this without seeing or needing to see the W-D thing. And I’d say that makes it “not a Thursday”

I thought this was brilliant. Can't imagine how hard it was to come up with cromulent dual-purpose clues.

Did anyone else think of "Into The Woods"? This is from the prologue:

[JACK'S MOTHER]
Son
We've no time to sit and dither
While her withers wither with her—

BTW Stephen Sondheim was a big cryptic crossword fan. He even composed a handful of them.

Oh my goodness, Mr Boroughs. What a puzzle. 

And I didn’t get it until I read the explanation above. But when I did… I got chills. The same chills as when I finished the Marshal puzzle (One L) a few months ago. 

This is a perfect Thursday puzzle for me. 

Well done!!
So clever. Thank you. I only got “W or D” when I read the article, thank goodness for WorDplay. ❤️

I got a pleasant surprise when the puzzle was all filled in.  Clever!  Great fun.  Only ONE cheat on a Thursday, which for me is pretty darn good.  (I knew the one honorific, but 'bwana' is new to me.)  Thank you, all of you who had a part.

Smoothly worked our way through the fill, but felt it was somehow more difficult than Thursday usually was for us.  Could not figure out why the circled letters were all 'D's, but not all the 'D's.  Haven't seen a Schrödinger puzzle in a while, and we prefer our cats all alive (even if only in our memories), so it was easy to simply enter all those 'D's.
It just proves how you fall into fixed ways of thinking without even realizing it!  If only we had been able to conceive of more 'W's in the grid.  Thanks for reminding us to always consider all the options.

A quick solve without ever getting the trick. The W-or-D Choice is really clever and I wish figuring that out had factored into my solve! Making the grid more difficult might have put too much pressure on figuring out that trick, but it's such a good revealer that I wish it could have paid off before reading the column!

Solved it without realizing the trick was involved, with Ds in every circle.   While the crossword creation was likely very challenging, the solve felt more like a Wednesday than a Thursday.  

Washboard is an instrument panel ?

Hi everyone,

On behalf of Wordplay, I'm just popping in to say that we are  thinking about the readers in Florida and those in North Carolina still affected by the aftermath of Hurricane Helene.
Nice puzzle but it feels very weird to clue SAHIB as Indian rather than Arabic.

A question--
While I appreciate the NYT XW's flexibility in entering rebus(-y) cells into the grid--"D," "W," "D/W," etc.--especially for those of us who are keyboard-challenged, will it still work if you enter some as "D" and others as "W"? In that case, one could fill the grid, and get a Gold Star, without ever comprehending the gimmick.

Of course, I don't always comprehend the gimmick, anyway.
Brilliant! Thank you, Grant.

Very clever. Found the theme answer early but couldn’t parse it as four words so shrugged and filled in the rest of the puzzle. I had DITHER but changed it to WITHER when I found PAW. Didn’t think about PAD. Having finished it I looked again at the theme, got it and spent a minute wondering why I chose W or D in the answers.

never got the theme. was thinking it was something to do with wd40. i still don't understand the 'four parts' of 'wordchoice?' had to come here to figure out what the author was getting at. lots of proper nouns that don't require solving anything. not great!

Only got the theme when I'd finished the thang. I had no bloody idear.
Excellent puzzle! Love it.

I picked this up at WRY/DRY HUMOR as I asked myself which one it was?  Then I noticed the tiny little circle.  Then I went back and noticed that my PAW could have been PAD and my WITHER could have been DITHER; that my COW could have been COD and my WASHBOARDS DASHBOARDS.  By then, there was only DAY AHEAD/WAY AHEAD and DISHES/WISHES to go.

Very very clever.  Very, very smooth.  This is one of those rare times when there is a really compelling and interesting reason for employing tiny little circles in a grid.

This is -- on a less-grand scale -- similar to the CLINTON/BOB DOLE puzzle of such great fame.  The type is described by that word I can never remember: the one that begins with an S and sounds somewhat like the kid piano player in the "Peanuts" cartoon.  I liked this puzzle a lot and think that it's very well conceived.
This was so fun and clever!!

Firstly, the constructor has a very cool name. Secondly, I'd like to think I would have figured it out on my own, but probably not. With the exception of WRY/DRY, each of the Schodinger squares has a plausible answer and a stretchy answer. Who has SOD in their garden? In mine, grass is something to be removed. Not complaining, just disappointed that I didn't get it before the W/Ds auto-filled.

Then she said, "Kiss me, big BWANA," so I kissed her big BWANA. Benny Hill still cracks me up.
Did not grok the rebus until nearing the end. Interesting Thursday,
I usually hate the gimmicky puzzles, but I enjoyed this one.

From a premise stand-point, this puzzle was awesome. Perfect use of Thursday trickiness. I was searching for the theme with all of the circled letters filled, and thank goodness I had one of them filled as a "W." Otherwise, I would have been looking for a theme revolving completely around the letter "D."

Phenomenal entry today. I had a ton of fun with this one.

Wow, this was a fun one! Like other folks, I didn't even catch on to the W/D theme until I read the column and went back to look at it again.

I'm looking forward to lots more from Mr. Boroughs!
Bravo!!

I got credit for finishing even though I made only one choice in each w/d space. After the fact I see that, for ex, cod and cow are major food sources. So shouldn't I have noted the 2 possibilities and filled in the rebus blocks myself to get credit for a solve?
I solved the puzzle but it took me way too long to make sense of the now obvious 51A answer. Oh well.

Thought I would PLOD and PLOW my WAY AHEAD without giving any thought to my DAY AHEAD, so it took a whopping 78 minutes to solve. I didn’t google anything until the very end when it wouldn’t complete even though it seemed finished. I said ENUF and turned out I had one misspelling! Amazing puzzle!

I’m disappointed in myself that I completely missed the trick until I was done and went back to think about what the circles were for.  Perhaps the emus were too lenient with us, accepting either W or D instead of requiring both.

That was fun! It would have been a nice touch to have something in there about WD-40!
About half my average Thursday time, which was nice, because the Bee took me forever today. Go figure.

Felt on the easy side for a Thursday. I enjoyed it. Favourite clue surrounded “stickier”

Sincerely,
Magician who has lost magic. (Ian)

Interesting theme, but I missed it entirely. After seeing D's in the first few circles I filled, I just assumed all of the circles should be filled with D's, so I filled them all in. Put in the revealer, but didn't immediately see how to parse it. Then I completed the puzzle and the W/D's appeared for me, ruining my chance to return to the revealer and figure it out on my own.

Cute Thursday puzzle, but SODding isn't "garden work". SOWing (and hoeing) are.

Interesting theme, but I missed it entirely. After seeing D's in the first few circles I filled, I just assumed all of the circles should be filled with D's, so I just filled them all in. Put in the revealer, but didn't immediately see how to parse it. Then I completed the puzzle and the W/D's appeared for me, ruining my chance to return to the revealer and figure it out on my own.

Cute Thursday puzzle, but SODding isn't "garden work". SOWing (and hoeing) are.

Lots of fun 😊👏🏻
I got the W or D trick, but then had to flyspeck for a mistake somewhere, which I finally found was having ODes instead of ODIC for the “Keats works”. Somehow I thought I had put in FISHTAIL for 3D but had the nonsensical FeSHTAIL. Duh 🤦🏼‍♀️ Thanks for the fun, Mr. Boroughs. Now I will go look up Schrödinger and his cat for the umpteenth time and see if I can understand it and remember it for the next time we have this type of puzzle. Maybe I’ll have another cup of coffee first.

I was determined to PLOW and PLOD my WAY AHEAD not giving any thought to my DAY AHEAD and solve this without looking up anything. Great puzzle with a dazzling theme but it was a workout, taking me a whopping 78 minutes to solve. And in the end I did have to say ENUF and google one thing because the damn thing wouldn’t solve. Turned out I had misspelled something!

I don’t know whether to be impressed or complain, but I managed to complete the puzzle, saw WORDCHOICE as describing the theme, and was completely mystified. Lost, I read the Rex Parker review and only then did it register that there were W or D versions of each theme answer. This was all after I completed the puzzle and just wanted to understand what I just solved. Weird. And impressive I guess.

This may be a question of cultural variation, but a person failing to take decisive action may dither, but I can’t find any sources that give that definition for wither.  Witter: there’s a good synonym.  Can anyone enlighten me?

I figured out the theme when there was just couple of letters to go. Could have been a smoother solve if I had gotten it earlier, but this was my very first Thursday solve without lookups or help so will not complain. Must have been a tricky one to construct with not only interchangeable letters but crossing interchangeable letters. Very nice.

You can fill the circled cells as if it were a rebus, that is, use the rebus button, and enter "W/D" or "D/W", and you will get credit for the right answer.  On my PC, but not my iPhone, the solution shows "W/D" in the circled cells.  This isn't convincing evidence when one claims this is not a rebus puzzle.  I'm not sure whether the NYT is sure whether or not this is a rebus puzzle.  Luckily I got the gold star without knowing whether or not this was a rebus puzzle.
As an ARIES it took me far too long to realize that a ‘bold ambitious type’ referred to my zodiac sign and not as I thought the typeface ‘Arial’ which I think would be a punnier and more fun clue…

What's the name of the resident circle opponent? Did she approve of this one? 😉 

Just curious.

I recall fondly those years when I was slowly climbing that  mountain, when my first correct Monday puzzle sent me over the moon, and the journey toward mastering all the days of the week was a labor of love and enjoyment.
Alas, now as I adapt to the effects of Alzheimer's, my Xword journey is moving slowly and steadily in the opposite direction. Today's puzzle lost me entirely. 
Perhaps I should try some "old timey medicines" (42D)...

Sorry, I don’t care about the fancy gimmick, this puzzle is otherwise dull as dishwater. None of the actual clues are interesting or intriguing, most of them are stale familiars. It’s a slog to get through.

I had solved the Timothy Polin puzzle from Thursday, March 1, 2018 earlier this week, so today's felt like déjà vu. https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2018/03/01 One person's "gimmick" is another person's brilliant puzzle-within-a-puzzle. I truly admire the constructors who can pull it off so nicely. Congrats to Grant Boroughs!

Well, today I learned Bwana. That B cost me the gold. But that’s ok. I didn’t understand the part about the “4” til I read the column, but the trick itself was a fun aha moment, the wry/dry humor was my light bulb. Agree that the fill itself was easy for a Thursday, but I’m not complaining.

If wishes were dishes, I’d already be eating supper.

Had to choose life over the word games this morning, but a fun puzzle to relax the brain after a busy day.

Now, which major food source animal will make my day’s end meat? Brisket?
Washboards as instrument panels?

I completely missed that the rebus option was available, and got the solve with just entering W's and one D in the various circled squares. As I was finishing up, I was feeling a little sad that there wasn’t a Thursday rebus to enjoy. Silly me.

I only had 2 "Ds".  Dry/wry and Day/way.  I changed them to all "W"s before finishing the puzzle.  When I saw the majority of 
"W" starts, I assumed, wrongly,  that W was the Way to go.  Then I completed 58A, and had to laugh. Of course, rebuses!  My puzzle was accepted with all W's.  I didn't know about Dr. Shroedinger having anything other than a cat.  He also has rebuses. What a fun puzzle. I enjoyed everything about it.  I like rebuses and am not put off by seeing them in a Thursday puzzle. This one was delightful. I certainly agree with you Deb, his puzzle is clever and elegant.

Grieve, and know you are not alone.

@Marshall Walthew A Schrödinger puzzle isn't exactly a rebus. In such a puzzle, you can put either letter--a W or a D--in each square and have a correct solve. So your solve was complete regardless of whether you used the W or the D in any of the squares. The xwordinfo.com answer key conveys this a little better, I think: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/10/2024

@Steve L "Schrodinger puzzle" - what a great term.  I'd never heard it before.  Makes perfect sense.

Thanks.

@Steve L I had a feeling that you had linked to “Carmelita.” Linda Ronstadt’s version is fine, but it’s hard to beat Warren Zevon’s original. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6xyuQG0IyGs

@Eric Hougland 

As I said above, the Ronstadt version is how I know of ECHO Park.

I think there's a reason that Linda is one of the greatest female voices of the late 20th centrury, and that Zevon toiled in relative obscurity.  I think her version beats his by a mile, and you can hear the difference starting in the first line, where he sings "Mary-achi music" as if he were a Brit saying "tack-os" and "saul-sa".

I think she also made one brilliant change in the lyrics, too, swapping "Smith and Wesson"--a gun--for "Smith Corona"--a bleepin' typewriter--pawned in order to buy heroin.

Zevon wrote several songs that Linda recorded--and, I'd say, elevated--including Hasten Down the Wind, Mohammed's Radio, and most notably, Poor Poor Pitiful Me.

The Wikipedia article asserts that Zevon would not have had a solo recording career if Ronstadt had not recorded his songs.

I doubt the reverse would be true.

Others may disagree, of course.

@Steve L @Eric Both versions are great, but there’s a certain depth and authenticity when a songwriter performs his/her own song. Especially one as gifted and tortured as Zevon. Zevon owes more to Jackson Browne than to Linda Ronstadt, I think. But his genius was recognized widely among artists, musical and literate, if not always by the record-buying masses. (Back in college, the Excitable Boy album made him a dorm favorite, though.) The Guardian had a good article about him. (Fun coincidence to see the reference to Carl Hiaassen after watching the season finale to Bad Monkey last night.) https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/aug/01/warren-zevon-werewolves-of-london-demons

@Bella 

There's no reason to change them to a WD.  The puzzle accepts either, so it's solved!
@Steve L It accepted my W/D fill.

@Aarglefarg 

I didn't say W/D wouldn't be accepted.  (Nor did I say D/W wouldn't be accepted.)

I said WD wouldn't be accepted.  (Similarly, neither would DW.)

The slash is needed to show that you see that they are alternatives, not a two-letter rebus.

@Steve L

WD is accepted in the app (at least for the iPhone).

@Marc A. Leaf 

There's obviously no way for me to test all the acceptable ways to enter the circled answers without having multiple accounts and tons of time, so I was just going by previous occurrences.

There's really no reason for WD or DW to be accepted without the slash, except to be super inclusive, but I guess the NYT programmers are bending over backwards to make sure everyone's happy--a fool's errand, in my opinion.  There's always someone who thinks not enough options are allowed, and someone else who thinks too many are.

I say "there's really no reason" because putting WD or DW implies that the answers are things like COWD or CODW, which they're not.  But I salute the effort for inclusion.

@Frennzy 

Nope, nope, nope.  This puzzle was not a rebus.

On the contrary, it was extremely forgiving.  For six different squares there were *two* acceptable answers, and pulling either out of the brain worked.  You didn't even need to see that there was another possibility.

So that means there are 2**6 = 64 different puzzles which are all correct, rather than the 1, in most puzzles.

@Frennzy 

Good then that one can solve this puzzle as a themeless - no rebus required, just fill out the answers as clued and not worry about the circles or revealer. No trick at all, in fact!!

@Andrzej I was lucky to have filled some of the theme entries with D and others with W, so that the revealer clicked right away. I can understand how it would be hard to see it if you'd had all Ws (or all Ds) in the circles. 

I don't know much about wedding registries, but as I understand it, it's a list of things you WISH for (and that you've already picked out at the store), and this often includes DISHES.

Ah, so the registry is not some official document? Thank you for the explanation.

In Poland people usually make a wish list when they are getting married but it's not called a registry - that word is largely reserved for official business, eg. we have a state-run marriage registry. My confusion was culture-based I see.

@Andrzej 

The previous replies omitted a key fact. A gift registry is usually (well, always in my experience) maintained by a particular store — say, Crate&Barrel (a popular housewares store here) or maybe Ikea. The store keeps track of what people buy so that the newlyweds don’t end up with something like three toasters.* The practice is a little mercenary, but it’s also efficient and practical. 

I think it used to be considered gauche for an engaged couple to say in conjunction with a wedding invitation “We’re registered at X,” so you had to ask the bride’s mother or someone else where they were registered. 

Gift registries have been around since at least when my parents were married in 1949. I used to have the list of gifts they received. They had sterling silver flatware for 10 or 12 people. Since that’s expensive, people gave only a few people. The registry helped ensure that my parents didn’t get 20 knives and eight forks. 

*(I like toast, and we used to have a vintage pop-up toaster that made the best regular toast ever, but when we moved, we gave it away. The toaster oven that accommodates bagels was more useful.)

@Eric Hougland 

Thanks for the details 🙂

In Poland these days wedding wish lists circulate via the internet, with wedding guests agreeing between themselves who gets what. The stores themselves do not get involved. At least that is what I have encountered. 

(I abhor rites and rituals, especially those with historical links to religion, and my wife is not big on them either. We also like to keep private things private. So we got married at city hall with just the official and the obligatory witnesses present, and then we had a small party at our favorite Spanish restaurant for 15 closest friends and family. There were no gifts or lists thereof. It was so simple! I loved it)

@Andrzej 

My husband and I had been together for over 30 years when we got married. We rented the entirety of a bed and breakfast in Vermont. Most of our guests stayed there with us for three nights. It was really quite nice.

Hi, EMUs!

@Bill a washboard (as a musical instrument) is commonly used in Zydeco (Cajun music), as well as old timey, jug band and other genres. I guess someone originally discovered the captivating sound of running a stick (or spoon, or something else) over the ridges of a washboard and started incorporating it into music. Nowadays, they design and manufacture them as instruments (sometimes called rub boards), often worn over the shoulders and hanging down in front of the chest. So, it’s an instrument, and it’s basically a panel with ridges 😊 https://youtu.be/cDZHELc00zQ?si=tuaWCWjX3d0fBj3Z

@Eric Hougland -- Yep, I did.  Thanks for noticing and remembering.  Here, lovingly reproduced for y'all, is my deathless comment from earlier today.  Note the 2nd paragraph:

I picked this up at WRY/DRY HUMOR as I asked myself which one it was?  Then I noticed the tiny little circle.  Then I went back and noticed that my PAW could have been PAD and my WITHER could have been DITHER; that my COW could have been COD and my WASHBOARDS DASHBOARDS.  By then, there was only DAY AHEAD/WAY AHEAD and DISHES/WISHES to go.

Very very clever.  Very, very smooth.  This is one of those rare times when there is a really compelling and interesting reason for employing tiny little circles in a grid.

This is -- on a less-grand scale -- similar to the CLINTON/BOB DOLE puzzle of such great fame.  The type is described by that word I can never remember: the one that begins with an S and sounds somewhat like the kid piano player in the "Peanuts" cartoon.  I liked this puzzle a lot and think that it's very well conceived.
